name: Apocryphal Traditions
description: Explore apocryphal and deuterocanonical texts excluded from mainstream biblical canons yet preserving ancient traditions.
overview: Apocryphal literature encompasses texts excluded from Protestant biblical canon but preserved in Catholic/Orthodox traditions, plus Jewish pseudepigrapha and Gnostic writings. These include: Books of Enoch describing fallen angels (Watchers), Nephilim giants, heavenly journeys, and apocalyptic visions; Book of Jubilees retelling Genesis with calendar emphasis; Tobit and Judith heroic narratives; Wisdom of Solomon; Maccabees historical books; and Gnostic gospels (Thomas, Mary, Philip). The texts preserve alternative perspectives on creation, angels, demons, afterlife, and divine wisdom often suppressed by orthodox authorities.

culturalContext.primarySources: Dead Sea Scrolls, Nag Hammadi library, Septuagint

sections.title: Books of Enoch
sections.body:
**1 Enoch:** Watchers (fallen angels) descend, teach forbidden knowledge, mate with human women producing Nephilim giants. Enoch journeys through heavens, receives cosmic revelations, witnesses divine judgment.

**2 Enoch:** Additional heavenly journey describing ten heavens, creation secrets, astronomical knowledge.

**3 Enoch (Hebrew Apocalypse):** Enoch transformed into angel Metatron, becomes scribe of heaven, reveals mystical Torah.

Enochian literature influenced apocalyptic thought, angelology, and concepts of fallen angels.
